subject: Psychology
title: The Roots of Prejudice
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Roots of Prejudice usable.

hook.text: A five-year-old already shows bias toward their own group. Nobody taught them. Where does prejudice begin?

buildup.text: Prejudice is a negative attitude toward a group involving stereotypes, negative feelings, and discrimination.

discovery.text: Social identity theory explains: we categorize people into groups, favor our own, and devalue outsiders.

twist.text: Even arbitrary groups show bias. In minimal group experiments, random team assignments produce in-group favoritism.

climax.text: Prejudice isn't just ignorance. It's a byproduct of how the brain categorizes the social world.

punchline.text: Bias is built into categorization. Awareness is the fix.

quiz.question: What does social identity theory explain?
options: We categorize people into groups and favor our own
Prejudice only exists in certain cultures
Everyone treats all groups equally by default
